images.description: Command Module Pilot in Apollo spacecraft operates the new quick-release outward opening hatch.
A helicopter hovers near the crawler transporter at Apollo launch complex 39 at KSC.
Aerial view of VAB at Apollo launch complex 39 at KSC.

Test subject Ronald C. Woods wears the new Integrated Thermal Micrometeorite Garment (TMG) which will be worn by Apollo astronauts during extravehicular activities in space on the surface of the moon.
An Apollo Command Module boilerplate is used to check out the release mechanism and instrumentation of the Land and Water Impact Facility at NASA s Manned Spacecraft Center in Houston.

Apollo Command Module boilerplate is subjected to impact forces like those of normal water landings or of almost any conceivable emergency landing at Land and Water Impact Facility at NASAs Manned Spacecraft Center in Houston
Astronaut Thomas K. Mattingly completed an altitude verification test of the Apollo Portable Life Support System (PLSS) flight unit 06/24/68.

Astronaut Fred W. Haise, Jr., left participates in a test of support equipment in the Spaceport's lunar module altitude chamber.  With Haise is George Dowling, consultant pilot for Grumman Aircraft Corporation, hilder of the IM.
An engineering set up illustrating the docking system of the Apollo spacecraft.
An engineering set up illustrating the docking system of the Apollo spacecraft.
LM upside down in KSC altitude chamber - mission unknown

Vice-President Spiro T. Agnew swears in the Administrator of NASA, Dr. Thomas O. Paine, in ceremonies conducted in the Vice-President's office. Members of the Administrator's family and staff witnessed the ceremony.
VP Spiro Agnew swears in NASA administrator Thomas Paine
VP Spiro Agnew swears in NASA administrator Thomas Paine
Launch Vehicle personnel pose at pad 39A
John B. Slight of the MSC Flight Support Division rides an original prototype of a lunar cycle under 1/6 gravity conditions aboard a KC-135 aircraft
